title: Focus and Self-Control
summary: Developing the ability to pay attention, remember rules, think flexibly, and exercise self-control.

details.content: Focus and self-control are foundational for learning and managing emotions. They help children filter distractions, control impulses, and persist through challenges.
A child resists the urge to interrupt during story time and waits for their turn to speak, showing self-control and attention.

content: Play games that require taking turns and following rules (e.g., Simon Says, Red Light Green Light).
Create routines to help children know what to expect.
Encourage mindfulness activities like deep breathing or focusing on sounds.
Break tasks into smaller steps to help maintain attention.

title: Perspective Taking
summary: Understanding what others think and feel, and seeing situations from different viewpoints.

details.content: Perspective taking builds empathy, cooperation, and effective communication. It helps children navigate social situations and resolve conflicts.
A child notices a friend is sad and asks if they want to play, showing awareness of another’s feelings.

content: Read stories and discuss how characters might feel or think.
Ask questions like, 'How do you think your friend felt when that happened?'
Role-play different scenarios to practice seeing things from another’s perspective.
Encourage children to listen actively to others.

title: Communicating
summary: Expressing thoughts, feelings, and ideas clearly and listening to others.

details.content: Strong communication skills are essential for building relationships, learning, and problem-solving. They help children express needs and understand others.
A child explains why they are upset instead of crying or yelling, using words to communicate their feelings.

content: Encourage children to use words to express their feelings and needs.
Model active listening by making eye contact and repeating back what you heard.
Play games that involve giving and following directions.
Ask open-ended questions to promote conversation.

title: Making Connections
summary: Recognizing patterns, relationships, and how things fit together.

details.content: Making connections helps children understand the world, solve problems, and apply knowledge in new situations.
A child notices that the leaves fall from trees in autumn and connects it to changes in weather.

content: Encourage sorting and categorizing activities (e.g., grouping toys by color or size).
Ask children to find similarities and differences between objects or ideas.
Use analogies and metaphors to explain new concepts.
Connect new experiences to things children already know.

title: Critical Thinking
summary: Analyzing information, making decisions, and solving problems thoughtfully.

details.content: Critical thinking enables children to evaluate information, make informed choices, and think creatively.
A child considers different ways to build a tower so it won’t fall over, testing and revising their ideas.

content: Ask 'why' and 'how' questions to encourage deeper thinking.
Present open-ended problems and brainstorm solutions together.
Encourage children to explain their reasoning.
Play games that involve strategy and prediction.

title: Taking on Challenges
summary: Approaching difficulties with resilience, persistence, and a positive attitude.

details.content: Facing challenges builds confidence, perseverance, and a growth mindset. It helps children learn from mistakes and keep trying.
A child keeps trying to tie their shoes even after several failed attempts, showing persistence.

content: Praise effort and persistence, not just success.
Model coping strategies for dealing with frustration.
Break big challenges into smaller, manageable steps.
Encourage children to try new things, even if they might fail.

title: Self-Directed, Engaged Learning
summary: Being motivated to learn, exploring interests, and taking initiative.

details.content: Self-directed learners are curious, motivated, and able to pursue knowledge independently. This skill supports lifelong learning.
A child chooses to research dinosaurs on their own and shares what they learn with others.

content: Offer choices in learning activities to foster autonomy.
Encourage questions and exploration of interests.
Provide resources and support for independent projects.
Celebrate curiosity and initiative.
